text:
Not a lawyer, etc., but have been following this case a bit, so my (possibly flawed) summary:

Previous decisions in this series of cases decided that APIs _are_ copyrightable. However, the current supreme court decision says that writing code that reimplements and/or conforms to that API is not necessarily an infringement of that copyright (i.e., is _fair use_), even if it leads to virtually identical code, because by the nature of APIs, there are a bunch of things where there is really only one way to do it. Or in legal-speak

> Held:  Google’s  copying  of  the  Java  SE  API,  which  included  only  those  lines of code that were needed to allow programmers to put their accrued talents to work in a new and transformative program, was a fair use of that material as a matter of law.

text:
Whether it was a good idea to allow APIs to be copyrightable in general is not entirely obvious. Is there really any creative freedom expressed when writing an API?

Fans of permissive free software licenses might prefer APIs not be copyrightable at all, while FSF-type folks actually prefer the copyright-maximalist approach here, because having APIs be copyrightable increases their leverage with the GPL.

In any case, the overall result (APIs are copyrightable, but reimplementation is fair use) seems like a reasonable-enough compromise to me.

text:
Well, it’s not my argument either way, but to quote from the EFF’s amicus brief [1]:

> The Ninth Circuit in _Sega_ acknowledged that the structure and design of computer programs can be “highly creative.” But as utilitarian articles, computer programs “contain many logical, structural, and visual display elements that are dictated by the function to be performed, by considerations of efficiency, or by external factors such as compatibility requirements and industry demands.”
and this matters because questions of whether something is utilitarian or functional, vs creative in a more artistic sense can make the difference between something that is copyrightable but not patentable, and something that is patentable but not copyrightable:

> Compare 35 U.S.C. § 101 (allowing patents on a “new and useful process”) with 17 U.S.C. §102(b) (disallowing copyright protection for processes or methods of operation). Patents, of course, also must be “creative,” but in patent law, unlike copyright law, “creative” merely means “novel and nonobvious” (see 35 U.S.C. §§102, 103).
One other relevant quote from the lower court rulings:

> To the extent that there are many possible ways of accomplishing a given task or fulfilling a particular market demand, the programmer’s choice of program structure and design may be highly creative and idiosyncratic. However, computer programs are, in essence, utilitarian articles — articles that accomplish tasks. As such, they contain many logical, structural, and visual display elements that are dictated by the function to be performed, by considerations of efficiency, or by external factors such as compatibility requirements and industry demands.
Their conclusion was that the Java API was creative enough to be copyrightable, but also noted that “[u]nder the Copyright Act, if a work is largely functional, it receives only weak protection” and this “weak protection” essentially provided Google a better claim in their _fair use_ argument that was ultimately upheld by the supreme court here.

[1] <https://www.eff.org/document/eff-pk-amicus-brief-oracle-v-google-second-appeal>
